page.title: 12CORNARD MERE
page.content: The Mere is an unusual,if not unique, type of habitat for south-west Suffolk. It is the remains of what was once a great lake in inter-glacial times.It still floods in winter and dries out completely by mid summer.A wide variety of wetland plants can be found, and the area of 5.26 hectares has been designated a Site of Special Scientific Interest.It is common land and up till the mid 1950's the land was grazed.It was left unmanaged until 1973,when Little Cornard Parish Council agreed to lease the site to the Suffolk Trust for Nature Conservation as a nature reserve There are many species of water plants to be seen, and the area attracts a wide variety of birds. Lizards,frogs and grass snakes have been reported,and insects are numerous and diverse.The Mere boasts one of Britain's rarest trees,the Black Poplar
